frontmatter.name: ANDRIY SYLCHUK
frontmatter.about: I started my career as a manual QA engineer, managed to achieve some success both in this area and in automation, became a team lead, then a project manager, and managed to become the first delivery manager in the Odesa office of DataArt, where I continue to work to this day. I combine the role of delivery with the role of the head of our development office in Odessa. I head the telegram channel about IT and interviews "Уютная Галера".

reports.description: I have extensive experience in all points raised in Tech Corners, since I immediately take 2 positions in our company, and I can discuss both sides of them.
reports.title: TeamLead and SoftSkills Tech Corners

frontmatter.name: OLEKSII PAVLENKO
frontmatter.about: In IT since 2014. I have worked with different technologies: Java, JavaFX, NodeJs, JavaScript, Typescript, C #, AngularJS, Angular, React. But above all, I specialize in Frontend. I like to start holy wars and participate :) I used to play basketball professionally, I can talk about this topic on long winter evenings

reports.description:
By default, JavaScript does not have a runtime validation check. As for the contracts that are developed within the team, we can be somewhat sure. Regarding the errors in the third party API we will only know on production.
Runtime Type Checking - adds an extra step to quality assurance and allows you quickly to respond on integration errors in real time.
reports.title: Contract protection on the Frontend side: how to organize runtime checking

frontmatter.name: DMITRIY TIMCHENKO
frontmatter.about: I managed to create my own startup (a service for ordering a taxi) and sell it. I love sports, outdoor activities and travel. I definitely take time for development and personal growth.

reports.description:
I will tell you three stories from practical experience. 
The first story is about how software skills helped to move from the position of Product manager to the position of Engineering manager. The second one will be about a person without experience in IT, but with strong communication, organisational, analytical skills, she was able to fully enter the role of Project manager in 5 months and fully fulfil her duties. 
The last topic is about how important it is to create a culture of feedbacks, holding 1-1 meetings, analysing employee satisfaction within the company/team.
reports.title: Tech Corner "How well-developed Soft skills help in career growth"

frontmatter.name: KSENIA REDUNOVA
frontmatter.about: OdessaJS resident since 2013. I've been working with JavaScript for ages, and have tried almost everything in JS-related technologies. My current interests are spread outside JS and include Agile, especially SAFe (I'm SPC), management and soft skills.

reports.description:
Agile tech corner:
 1. Scrum: pain or gain?
 2. Agile at Scale: why and how?
Soft skills tech corner: 
 3. Work-life balance when working remotely
reports.title: Agile and Soft skills tech corners

frontmatter.name: ANASTASIA NECHEPORENKO
frontmatter.about:
Developer with experience working with Back End and Front End.
I wrote my first program about 10 years ago, and since then I can't imagine myself without coding.

reports.description: Using Nx in large application development. How does business benefit from using Nx? Which tools can help developers? How to control the quality? Things to consider before using Nx.
reports.title: Building Angular Apps with Nx

frontmatter.name: PAVEL KUTSENKO
frontmatter.about: I live in Odessa. I love travelling with my family. I get pleasure from working remotely and the opportunity to work from different locations. I love to develop and learn new technologies.

reports.description: I want to discuss the topic of burnout. Moreover, consider this issue not only from the side of work, but also from the rest of a person's life. Hope to give advice so that everyone can analyse their condition, understand what influenced it and how to deal with it.
reports.title: Frameworks and SoftSkills Tech Corners

frontmatter.name: ANDRII TROYAN
frontmatter.about: 5 years in development, taught Computer sciences in India, adores traveling and hiking.

reports.description: The aim of this lecture is to expose the benefits of using NestJS for microservice architecture. I'll try to explain the core features of the framework and why it could be useful. We'll start with the basic principles of microservices and finish with a real example.
reports.title: Developing Microservices with NestJS

frontmatter.name: OLEKSII HONCHAR
frontmatter.about: I'm a GettingThingDone IT guy with a long story about software development and team management in different domains, processes, and technologies. I would describe myself as a highly autonomous and collaborative problem solver. I'm strong in putting things together and making them work.

reports.description: Features of the implementation of specific business tasks. Features of the use of an electron with cross-platform development. Issues of integrating various devices and performance analysis.
reports.title: Using Electron in the development of a corporate message-video-phone platform

frontmatter.name: BORYS MOHYLA
frontmatter.about: 6 years in software development.Co-founder of Vinnytsia JS conference. Mentor at Vinnytsia IT academy. Interested in ML and VR, likes thinking a lot and coding a bit.

reports.description:
Nowadays, many people use GraphQL, but not everyone knows how to design a GraphQL schema.  And those who do it correctly and optimized - units.
 In this topic, we'll look at how not to do what major design mistakes developers make.  We will also discuss the best practices of GraphQL schema design, development trends, and subtleties of the process.
reports.title: GraphQL schema design

frontmatter.name: SERGEY NEMCHINSKIY
frontmatter.about: Sergey Nemchinskiy is the CEO and Owner of the educational company foxmindEd. He's also a keynote speaker at many project management conferences and a blogger. Has 20+ years of experience in development, especially 15 in Java. Worked as a Project Manager at Ciklum, Team Lead at Luxoft, NetCracker at IntroPro.

reports.description: Nowadays developers are constantly facing different changes - starting from career issues and up to self-development. Unfortunately, lack of time doesn't allow them to complete everything. During my speech, we'll talk about priorities, how to get rid of unnecessary things, and not to waste time.
reports.title: How to be a good developer and stay in touch with the changes that happen so fast?

frontmatter.name: SERGIY BABICH
frontmatter.about: The Main Viking of Ukrainian IT, founder and organizer of the conference LvivCSS, developer with more than 10 years of experience. He is interested in mentoring and teaching, which allows him to transfer the accumulated knowledge and bring young professionals to the world of IT. He likes old and time-tested things, that’s why he is a fan of Black Sabbath and HTML, but always tries to keep up with the times and even writes on React.

reports.description:
Why did I not used React earlier? Because I can't stand Redux. My opinion is that it brings more issues than it solves and makes you handle state handling instead of handling state.

But now I am using React and feel quite happy without Redux. How? Why? Let me tell you about this in my talk, share some secrets of happy Redux-less life, and show you some very complicated examples that can ease life. At least mine.
reports.title: Is there React world without Redux?

frontmatter.name: PAVEL GALUSHKO
frontmatter.about: I have been programming for more than 20 years. Was a web developer for more than 10 years. Now I am a developer and Tech Lead in Python for Machine Learning

reports.description:
Myth#1: we don't need a good code. Myth#2: we don't need functionality. Myth#3: architecture is not for us.

We're going to observe all these myths and dispel most of them at the conference
reports.title: Good code myths

positions.position: Tech Lead of Machine Learning dev team

frontmatter.name: MYKHAILO SOBKO
frontmatter.about:
More than 10 years in software development as a WebDev, Team Lead, and Engineering Manager.

In my current position, I'm responsible for the resource management of the distributed dev team (200+ engineers) and people management of 50 engineers in Ukraine, India, and Columbia. Main focus on recruiting, hiring, training, mentoring, performance management and engineering leadership"

reports.description:
What are the top competencies of a great Teamlead?

- hiring
- team building
- motivation
- negotiations with stakeholders
- conflict management
- stress and burnout
- dismissal
- life after team lead position
reports.title: The TeamLead of my Mother's friend

frontmatter.name: MAKSYM KLYMYSHYN
frontmatter.about: I'm a full-stack software engineer and have the most experience with Clojure, Python, and JavaScript-based projects. In the last couple of years, I'm working mostly in a Software Architect roles as well as engineering leadership roles here at Takeoff Technologies, the robotic warehouse solution for picking groceries. My professional interest lies in the areas of leadership, product management, org architecture, distributed systems, information science, and functional languages.

reports.description: To be published
reports.title: What is so special about Micro Frontends pattern value proposition?

frontmatter.name: OLEKSII NOVOKHATSKYI
frontmatter.about: I am a Software Engineer, in work use JavaScript and Golang. Helped to start the careers of a dozen junior developers as a mentor (node.js / react / angular), conducted about a hundred interviews with developers from more than 20 countries. I write technical articles and speak at online / offline conferences. Currently work on own projects

reports.description: Despite the rapid development of Node.js, there are still problems with CPU-bound (intensive) tasks. One of the solutions is to use other programming languages. In this research, I want to reveal some possibilities and options for using Golang, learn more about this approach
reports.title: Golang usage in development of Node.js applications (Node.js: In Go we trust)

frontmatter.name: ANDREY KUCHERENKO
frontmatter.about: About

reports.description: Reflections on: What does today's world expect from engineers? What does it take to be an Advanced Engineer? How to grow as an engineer?
reports.title: How to become advanced engineer?

frontmatter.name: ANTON CHEREDNIKOV
frontmatter.about: About

reports.description: Let's talk about GraphQL: we will compare its advantages and disadvantages over other approaches to organizing client-server communication (REST, gRPC...). We will see how to cook GraphQL in micro-service world and which approach (schema stitching, merging or federation) is better and when
reports.title: NodeJS & GraphQL cookbook. Let’s talk about micro-services

frontmatter.name: LILIIA KARPENKO
frontmatter.about: I have been working as a FE developer for almost 5 years, full-stack for 3 years, now I am TeamLead. Mostly I work with Nodejs and React. All kinds of projects, starting with websites and developing big platforms.

reports.description: Microarchitecture is becoming more and more popular because of the wide use of integrations. Companies are switching from mono repositories to micro repositories and cloud. But what about frontend? I'll share my own experience on this topic.
reports.title: Microfrontends with React

frontmatter.name: DMITRIY GUSEV
frontmatter.about: About

reports.description: I'm going to share my experience and my pain, during swagger plugins development. I'll tell you about opportunities they give us, lack of documentation, and stubs I had to write.
reports.title: Is there Javascript on Swagger plugins?

frontmatter.name: YAROSLAV DVOROVENKO
frontmatter.about: People, people and people - these are my 3 main values. I adore communicating, sharing, discussing etc. It's the third time I'm a part of OdessaJS. Join the conference to experience the future.

reports.description: Long time ago we used handshakes to confirm a deal, now it's time of documentation but everything will change in future. In my speech I'll tell you about Blockchain and smart contracts. Moreover, we'll write a smart-contract during the second part of the speech.
reports.title: Ethereum smart contracts on js

frontmatter.name: NICK LOTOTSKIY
frontmatter.about: More than 20 years in software development. Conducts all steps from QA to DevOps Evangelist position. Nick started to use JS in 2008 and is still in love with this language. Nick's current duties are DevOps evangelist. Nick makes Namecheap teams cross-functional and adds DevOps philosophy to the whole company.

reports.description: There is a big problem in a project when you can't understand what happens with your application. Logs help you realize this. Unfortunately, engineers do not see any sense in the logging. Why do we write logs? How do we need to write logs? Why this is so important - in the following lecture I'll tell you about these things.
reports.title: Logs. How do they affect on my life?

frontmatter.name: ROMAN SAVITSKYI
frontmatter.about: Roman Savitskiy is a Co-Founder @BeerJS Zhytomyr, Co-Organizer frontend://zt, Arbiter DevChallenge2019. He's an active member of our community and helps to develop it, was a part of a Program Committee in 2019-2020, and invites you to join our conference in 2021

reports.description:
React, Angular, Vue, Svelte: are these networks essential in software development or they just replace JavaScript because of lack of knowledge? Who are you, JS developer? If you know only JavaScript, probably, it'll be difficult to grow your career without Docker, Redis, GraphQL, React, Angular, Node, etc.

I'll tell you more about frameworks and technologies to sort things out.
reports.title: * * * * * * *, JS, * * * * * * *

frontmatter.name: YURII ARTYUKH
frontmatter.about: An experienced coder, who had replaced the usual profession with unusual animation and working with WebGL. I liked it so much and was carried away, so I want to share it and inspire people.

reports.description: In my work i usually do something weird, animated, on the edge of performnce. So i decided to share couple of curious cases of using math and some interesting weird tech during frontend development.
reports.title: How I came up with my talk

frontmatter.name: VIKTOR TURSKYI
frontmatter.about: I am in software development for more than 15 years already. 9 years ago I have created a software development agency in Ukraine - WebbyLab, now there are approx. 100 people. I was lucky to be involved in a lot of projects (in total more than 100, as a software architect in 60+) and always happy to share our successes and mistakes we did :) I spent a lot of weekends doing optimizations in the process of software product development. It is cool when you are a software engineer and CEO at the same time.

reports.description: I suppose, that there are 3 points that make you a good developer. On of them is the understanding of how things work. However, I see a lot of programmers that are not acquainted with basics and make typical mistakes while working. I'll tell you how we resolve this @WebbyLab.
reports.title: Developers baseline. What is it?
